par.text: Magnesium is a silvery-white, light metal. On contact with air it forms a superficial coat of magnesium oxide - MgO. Magnesium is flammable. In the presence of air it burns with a dazzlingly bright flame. Magnesium reacts with water at elevated temperatures. It is a good conductor of electricity. It was named after the city of Magnesia in ancient Greece. Magnesium was
first isolated by the English chemist Humphry Davy in 1808.
